Mobogo.name: 沼原魔蟾 Mobogo
Mobogo.publicNotes: 沼原魔蟾是一种巨大的、居住在沼泽中的怪物，它集巨大蟾蜍和邪恶龙的最坏的特点于一身。懒惰、残忍、贪婪，这些可恶的生物在最古老、最原始的沼泽中筑巢。以这些地方为家的沼蜍人崇拜沼原魔蟾，把他们当做活着的半神，定期带来食物和贵重的祭品，以免自己成为沼原魔蟾永远填不满的胃口的下一个牺牲品。
Mobogo.hp: 再生30 (酸液、寒冷或火焰使其失效)

Song of the Swamp.name: 沼泽之歌 Song of the Swamp
Song of the Swamp.description:
频率 每10分钟一次

效果 沼原魔蟾发出响亮的蛙鸣。50尺内所有沼蜍人和沼原魔蟾在伤害骰、对抗恐惧效果的豁免检定上获得+2状态加值，持续1轮。范围内的其他生物必须尝试@Check[type:will|dc:27]豁免。

成功 生物不受影响，并且临时免疫24小时。

失败 生物陷入@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{缓慢 Slowed 1}，持续[[/br 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4轮}。

大失败 生物陷入@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{缓慢 Slowed 2}，持续[[/br 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4轮}。

Swamp Stride.name: 沼泽阔步 Swamp Stride
Swamp Stride.description: 沼原魔蟾无视沼泽地形特征造成的困难地形。

Tongue Grab.name: 蛙舌攫抓 Tongue Grab
Tongue Grab.description:
若沼原魔蟾用蛙舌命中1个生物，那么该生物会被@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{擒抱 Grabbed}。与一般的擒抱不同，该生物不会陷入禁足，但是也无法移动至沼原魔蟾的蛙舌触及范围之外。

生物可以通过命中AC 27并造成至少10点挥砍伤害来切断蛙舌。尽管这么做不会对沼蜍斥候造成伤害，但它可以使沼原魔蟾无法再次使用蛙舌打击，直至沼原魔蟾在1轮后重新长出蛙舌。

沼原魔蟾可以在不解除擒抱的前提下移动，只要被擒抱的生物位于它蛙舌的触及范围内。

Tongue Reposition.name: 蛙舌移位 Tongue Reposition
Tongue Reposition.description:
沼原魔蟾尝试移动被它蛙舌攫抓的一个生物。沼原魔蟾投掷一次运动检定，对抗目标的强韧DC。

如果成功，沼原魔蟾可以将生物拽至蛙舌触及范围内的任一空间内。如果它愿意的话，可以将被舌头擒抱的生物改为用它的嘴来擒抱。

cXcE5HUwD2KD7fgp.name: 再生30 (酸液、寒冷或火焰使其失效)

Dramofir.name: 织梦妖 Dramofir
Dramofir.publicNotes: 织梦妖这种生物拥有难以理解的意图和不可思议的力量，它们来自幻梦境(Dreamlands)，在多元宇宙中蹒跚前行，寻找梦境融入他们宽大的长袍。在主物质位面，很少有人敢轻视织梦妖；人们尊重它们，满心希望它们带走选定受害者的梦境就立刻离开。大部分时候，事情正如人们所愿。然而，时不时，在吸取某人梦境时，织梦妖会在毫无理由的情况下毫无预警地杀害它们的受害者。

ENpP2o2H3ia9c6NJ.name: 超现实解剖学 Surreal Anatomy
ENpP2o2H3ia9c6NJ.description: 织梦妖对精准伤害和重击额外伤害拥有10点抗性。若抗性值高于额外伤害值，织梦妖将额外伤害减至0，但这不减少打击的正常伤害。

BskkanKxSINfDBr9.name: 苦乐交织的梦 Bittersweet Dreams
BskkanKxSINfDBr9.description:
织梦妖挥动它们的长袍，将长袍中的梦栩栩如生地展现在观众眼前。@Template[type:emanation|distance:30]{30尺弥漫}内的每个生物都必须尝试@Check[type:will|dc:34]豁免，否则将被厌倦支配。

大成功 生物不受影响，且对苦乐交织的梦临时免疫24小时。

成功 生物在攻击、豁免、技能检定上获得-1状态减值，且生物身上的情绪效果被压制，持续1轮。

失败 如同成功，但生物还获得@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{缓慢 Slowed 1}，持续[[/br 1d4 #Duration Bittersweet Dreams]]{1d4轮}。

大失败 如同成功，但生物还获得@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{缓慢 Slowed 1}，状态减值为-2，持续1分钟。

@Compendium[pf2e.bestiary-effects.4FginnDcOt4wfedf]{效果: 苦乐交织的梦}

LtMnRFGdEZ9u0QFh.name: 采梦 Pluck Dream
LtMnRFGdEZ9u0QFh.description:
需求 织梦妖与一个@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{失去意识 Unconscious}或睡眠中的生物邻接。

效果 织梦妖舔了舔这个生物的前额，将手放在舔舐过的地方，吸出这个生物的梦境融入长袍。

如果目标受到任何改变其梦境的心灵效果的影响，例如@Compendium[pf2e.pathfinder-bestiary-2.Y9SDbANT1DWI1DKU]{活化梦境 Animate Dream's}的无尽噩梦诅咒或@Compendium[pf2e.spells-srd.Uqj344bezBq3ESdq]{梦魇术 Nightmare}法术，则织梦妖会尝试反制该效果（反制调整值[[/r 1d20+26 #Counteract]]{+26}）。否则，织梦妖会从该生物身上吸走一个美梦，而目标必须尝试一次@Check[type:will|dc:36]豁免。

成功 生物不受影响。

失败 生物陷入@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{呆滞 Stupefied 1}，直到完成一次完整休息。

大失败 如同失败，但生物陷入@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{呆滞 Stupefied 2}，且织梦妖对生物施放6环法术@Compendium[pf2e.spells-srd.FhOaQDTSnsY7tiam]{修改记忆 Modify Memory}。

Ancient Underworld Dragon.name: 古伏藏龙 Ancient Underworld Dragon
Ancient Underworld Dragon.publicNotes:
伏藏龙体现着构造板块间的压力，热泉后的热力，和世界成型时点燃的火光。作为天生的炼金术师，他们与生俱来就了解反应物和催化剂。虽然有些龙在研究金属反应中魔法的影响，但大多数伏藏龙都专心囤积财宝。他们满世界寻找切割过的宝石和用珍贵金属制作的神器，这两者他们都视作大地馈赠的精华所在。

伏藏龙看上去粗犷而锋利；他们的鳞片发着光仿若内部过热，他们的毛发摇曳着如同火舌。他们的目光后有着强烈的火焰燃烧，暗示着他们一个念头即可燃物，他们的呼吸让空气产生涟漪即是他们体内蕴含热量的最好证明。

帝龙，得名于龙帝国（the Dragon Empires），是人形种族到来之前的天夏（Tian Xia）守护者，五种强大而对的立力量的具现。与其他真龙不同，帝龙深度参与着人类事务。其中一些依然维持神秘感，装作隐士，而另一些则保持高调，公开统治着某些势力。天夏的文化也相应地崇敬着龙，将龙描绘成神明，或则他们的先祖。但不是所有龙都被崇拜，因为这些生物大多数都行事邪恶。

龙之五行 Draconic Cycles

五种元素是帝龙魔力的基石，影响着他们与一切事物的关系，特别是与他们之中不同种类的关系。这些元素以两个循环相互联系。第一个循环中，每个元素两两相生：木生火，火生土，土生金，金生水，水生木。第二个循环中，则两两相克：木克土，土克水，水克火，火克金，金克木。

每种帝龙都代表着一种元素，并拥有四种与相生相克有关的能力。比如，森龙——与木相通——生火，由水所生，克土，为金所克。

rvv40f4QmFMFlF5L.name: 颚咬 Jaws
rvv40f4QmFMFlF5L.description: 若未为水所克，额外造成3d6火焰伤害。

Smoke Vision.name: 烟视 Smoke Vision
Smoke Vision.description: 烟不会削弱伏藏龙的视觉；他们忽视由烟带来的@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{隐蔽 Concealed}状态。

Countered by Water.name: 为水所克 Countered by Water
Countered by Water.description:
如果伏藏龙受到了具有寒冷或水特征法术的伤害，他们体内的火属相魔法将被暂时抑制。

直到他们下个回合结束，他们攻击骰承受-1环境惩罚，他们的颚咬攻击不再造成火焰伤害，失去闷热灵光。

如果龙使用了吐息则限制结束。

@Compendium[pf2e.bestiary-effects.81XYZZ3H0GL8thdQ]{效果: 为水所克}

ZFhHkksQnaNOI9Rk.name: 由木所生 Fed by Wood
ZFhHkksQnaNOI9Rk.description:
当伏藏龙被一个木制武器攻击或被带有植物特征的法术影响，龙内在的火焰本质将因获得燃料而旺盛。他们的吐息获得充能，龙的颚咬附带的火焰伤害增加一个伤害骰直到龙的下个回合结束。

@Compendium[pf2e.bestiary-effects.4FMFRlEC923CnLI7]{效果: 由木所生}

Sweltering Heat.name: 闷热 Sweltering Heat
Sweltering Heat.description:
@Template[type:emanation|distance:10]{10尺} @Compendium[pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.v61oEQaDdcRpaZ9X]{灵光}

每个在灵光范围内结束回合的生物必须成功通过一次@Check[type:fortitude|dc:35]豁免，否则在灵光范围内会陷入@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.HL2l2VRSaQHu9lUw]{疲乏 Fatigued}状态。

Adamantine Claws.name: 精金爪 Adamantine Claws
Adamantine Claws.description: 龙的爪子中灌入了精金。他们的爪抓打击忽略物体一半的硬度。

Breath Weapon.name: 吐息 Breath Weapon
Breath Weapon.description:
龙向60尺内射出一个对@Template[type:burst|distance:30]{30尺爆发}范围造成[[/r {14d6}[fire]]]{14d6火焰伤害}的火球（@Check[type:reflex|dc:39|basic:true]豁免）。豁免失败的生物还将受到@Localize[PF2E.PersistentDamage.Fire3d6.success]。

龙不能在[[/br 1d4 #Recharge Breath Weapon]]{1d4轮}内再次使用吐息。

Coiling Frenzy.name: 盘绕狂暴 Coiling Frenzy
Coiling Frenzy.description: 龙以任意顺序进行一次爪抓和尾击打击，两次打击须选择相同目标。如果任意打击命中，龙自动@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{擒抱 Grabs}目标。

Draconic Momentum.name: 龙之威势 Draconic Momentum
Draconic Momentum.description: 当龙在一次打击中造成重击时，它立刻为吐息充能。

Scorch Earth.name: 焦土 Scorch Earth
Scorch Earth.description:
龙钻入地下，以掘地速度掘地移动，然后烧灼@Template[type:emanation|distance:60]{60尺弥漫}范围的土地。

区域内地表上的生物受到[[/r {8d6}[fire]]]{8d6火焰伤害}（@Check[type:fortitude|dc:37|basic:true]豁免），大失败将陷入@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{力竭 Enfeebled 1}一分钟。

Terra-Cotta Garrison.name: 兵马俑卫队 Terra-Cotta Garrison
Terra-Cotta Garrison.publicNotes:
兵马俑守护古代统治者的陵墓，在那里不休不眠地警戒，只有当入有入侵者闯入盗墓或玷污陵墓时才会活动起来。每个战士都是用粘土精心制作而成，并各自具有独特的特征。

这些被制造出来的战士作为训练有素的小队紧密协作，击退入侵者。

Aim as One.name: 弓箭齐发 Aim as One
Aim as One.description: 部队进行一次远程齐射，射程100尺，对@Template[type:burst|distance:10]{10尺爆发}范围造成[[/r 3d8+11]]伤害（@Check[type:reflex|dc:25|basic:true]豁免）。如果卫队规模被缩减至8格或更小，则爆发范围减少为@Template[type:burst|distance:5]{5尺}。

Raise Shields.name: 举起盾墙 Raise Shields
Raise Shields.description: 部队举起盾墙，效果如同单个生物@Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.xjGwis0uaC2305pm]{举起盾牌 Raise a Shield}。

Strike as One.name: 整齐划一 Strike as One
Strike as One.description:
A 到 T

频率 每轮1次

效果 卫队对5尺内的所有生物进行近战攻击（@Check[type:reflex|dc:30|basic:true]豁免）。该伤害取决于花费的动作：

A [[/r {2d8}[slashing]]]{2d8挥砍伤害}.

D [[/r {3d8+10}[slashing]]]{3d8+10挥砍伤害}.

T [[/r {4d8+13}[slashing]]]{4d8+13挥砍伤害}.

Troop Movement.name: 部队移动 Troop Movement
Troop Movement.description: 当部队行走时，它首先以一个自由动作重整队列，聚集成20尺*20尺方格的队列（减去任何损失的方格），然后以满速度移动。它在移动时如同一个巨形生物那般；举例来说，如果任何方格进入了困难地形，则整个部队都需要花费额外的移动力。

Terra-Cotta Soldier.name: 兵马俑士兵 Terra-Cotta Soldier
Terra-Cotta Soldier.publicNotes:

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-effects.2YgXoHvJfrDHucMr]{效果：举起盾牌}

Kongamato.name: 碎舟龙 Kongamato
Kongamato.publicNotes:
虽然碎舟龙与翼龙相似，并且来自近似的时代，但它们其实是龙类的一个原始分支。它们脑子不算很好使，也缺乏龙族所拥有的的强大魔法，但碎舟龙拥有一个超自然坚硬的喙，可以凿穿任何难以置信的致密物质。虽然它的喙看起来是非常棒的战利品，但碎舟龙死后喙上的魔法也就消失了，所以用它的喙制造武器的尝试都以失败告终。

虽然它们生活在沼泽和其他相对安静的水域，但碎舟龙更喜欢在河流和小溪环境中捕猎，因为活水总会吸引新的猎物。它们捕猎一切，并且很清楚它们强大的喙能击沉船只和木法。它们具有像龙一样贪婪的外表。虽然碎舟龙对物质财富和社会权力漠不关心，但它们占据大片猎场，会暴力攻击任何潜在的竞争对手，贪婪地屠戮领地内的大型动物，留下只吃了一半的尸体，根本不考虑将来还有没有食物。

当碎舟龙所声称的领土中包含某个社区时，那里的人别无选择，只能想办法捕杀邪恶的捕食者，或雇佣冒险者来完成这个任务。碎舟龙如此饥肠辘辘，一只就能毁灭整群的牲畜，威胁整个社区的安全。和它们的龙类亲戚不同，碎舟龙从不讨价还价，通过祭祀来安抚它们的尝试也不会有任何效果。

Attack of Opportunity.name: 借机攻击 Attack of Opportunity

Boat Breaker.name: 破船者 Boat Breaker
Boat Breaker.description: 碎舟龙的喙异常坚硬。它们的喙啄打击无视任何物品的一半硬度。

Flying Strafe.name: 飞掠 Flying Strafe
Flying Strafe.description: 碎舟龙以最大速度飞行，并且在行动中的任意地点进行两次翼拍打击。每次打击必须针对不同目标。

Wailing Dive.name: 哀鸣俯冲 Wailing Dive
Wailing Dive.description:
碎舟龙飞行，并且发出可怕的尖叫。每个碎舟龙飞过的生物必须通过@Check[type:will|dc:30]豁免，否则陷入@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{惊惧 Frightened 1}（大失败则@Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{惊惧 Frightened 2}）。

进行豁免后，生物暂时免疫此能力1小时。在移动结束之后，碎舟龙可以进行一次喙啄打击。

Grioth Cultist.name: 格里欧斯邪教徒 Grioth Cultist
Grioth Cultist.publicNotes:
格里欧斯邪教徒代表了他们最低层的无悔信徒——古老神话的崇拜者，他们的任务是领导进入新世界的侦查任务。虽然在指挥系统中阶级高于斥侯，但他们在整个宗教阶级制度中只占据了低下的位置。 虽然低语的传言描述了将世界从太阳中剥离所需的传奇仪式，但这些邪教徒并没有学习这种强大的魔法。这样的秘密留给了格里欧斯的大祭司，他们总是最后一个到达被殖民的世界。

大多数格里欧斯崇拜外神（Outer God）奈亚拉托提普的众多化身之一，尽管有些格里欧斯崇拜古老神话中的其他实体，如阿撒托斯（Azathoth）、宁布洛斯（Nhimbaloth）或犹格·索托斯（Yog-Sothoth）。在极为罕见的情况下，如果一个格里欧斯被从他们的社会中切断，并有机会探索其他宗教，他们仍然会倾向于与星星或夜晚有关的信仰，如黛丝娜（Desna）或宗-库山（Zon-Kuthon）。然而，这些格里欧斯被他们的同类所厌恶，被视为危险的异端分子。

漂离其恒星轨道的行星在飘过黑色帷幕（Dark Tapestry）时变得寒冷而没有生命力。 这些死寂的世界被称为格里欧斯的可怕生物所觊觎，他们在这些漂泊的世界上忍受着可怕的寒冷，并将它们转化为专门供奉古老神话（Elder Mythos）中黑暗之神的行星神庙。从这些冰冻黑暗的堡垒中，格里欧斯寻找温暖的、有生命力的世界，通过禁忌的仪式将它们从各自的太阳上扯弄出来，这个过程往往需要数代人的时间。

一个邪教徒通常会带领一支格里欧斯斥侯队，这支队伍在农村居民区的边缘寻找一个废弃或被遗忘的地方作为他们最初的入侵点。经过数代人的努力，格里欧斯的定居点逐渐强大，并征服了周围的文化，最终，强大的格里欧斯从星空中降临，开始下一阶段的星球征服。

格里欧斯讲一种由颤音和咔嚓声组成的语言。虽然能够说其他语言，但他们以干涩、粗哑的声音来发声。由于格里欧斯有翅膀、蠕动的尾巴和四眼蝙蝠般的面孔，许多文化人误以为它们与邪恶的外层位面（Outer Planes）有关，但它们在很大程度上属于这个现实。

Grioth Scout.publicNotes:
在一个新的世界上最先遇到的格里欧斯是斥候。斥候通常经由单向传送门从他们的家园出发，在浩瀚的太空中旅行，格里欧斯斥候从未期望再次看到他们的家园，因为格里欧斯领导层通过将他们搁置在新世界来确保对殖民化努力的真正奉献。

Clockwork Spy.name: 发条密探 Clockwork Spy
Clockwork Spy.publicNotes:
工程师、技术专家和具有机械天赋的巫师们利用发条密探——能够录音和回放音频的超小型蜘蛛构装体——暗中监视他们的敌人或窃取竞争对手的秘密。它们纤细的身躯和脆弱的部件使它们不适合战斗；事实上，大多数创造者都会给发条密探加上自毁机制，以确保一旦这种间谍行为败露，自己不会被追查。

发条机械是错综复杂的机器，由技艺高超的工程师精心制造。虽然它们的创造过程包含了一些魔法，但它们本质上是机械，里面塞满了精密调整的齿轮和弹簧，严丝合缝，协同工作。

发条机械内坚固的主发条必须上紧，才能提供装置所需的能量。一些较大的发条机械包含一系列弹簧，用于不同的肢体，每个肢体都需要分别上紧发条。发条工匠在制作发条机械时会创造一个独特的金属钥匙；上发条时通常需要把钥匙插入机器的背面，然后顺时针旋转。更大的发条机构需要更大的力量来转动钥匙，而且通常有更大的钥匙来提供更大的扭矩——有些甚至需要一整队人上发条，而不是单人操作。给发条程序编程需要用到钥匙和能正确设置程序的相关知识，这些信息通由发条机械的创造者或所有者持有。

lL49wJa4ig4V0ag1.name: 录音 Record Audio
lL49wJa4ig4V0ag1.description:
发条密探能将@Template[type:emanation|distance:25]{25尺}内的所有声音录在它携带的价值1gp的一小块宝石上。发条密探能在一块宝石上录最多1小时的音频。一旦开始录音，它就不能提前中止，也不能对已经录有音频的宝石进行复盖。

一些发条机械携带有多枚宝石，让它们能进行一系列的录音行动。发条机械可以区分不同种类的生物，但是无法分辨具体的个体。

发条密探可以通过一个动作来开始或停止播放录音。通过@Check[type:thievery|dc:14|traits:action:disable-device]检定的@Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{解除装置 Disable a Device}可以从发条密探上移除或安装一块宝石，如果检定失败，宝石不会损坏但所有录音会被消除且该宝石也不能被用来录音。

zdb8RR0jcIIol6on.name: 上发条 Wind-Up
zdb8RR0jcIIol6on.description:
活动时间24小时, 解除@Check[type:thievery|traits:action:disable-device|dc:14], 待机

要让发条机械运转，必须由另一个生物用一把独特的钥匙给它上发条。这需要1分钟时间。一旦上紧发条，它们能在列出的时间内活动，通常为24小时，时间耗尽之后它们就无法察觉周围的环境且无法行动，直到再次被上紧发条。一些发条机械的能力在使用时需要以减少活动时间为代价。它们消耗的活动时间不能超过当前剩余的活动时间，一旦活动时间为0，它们就会立即关机。如果不清楚发条机械上一次上发条是什么时候，大多数发条机械的管理员都会在早上8点上发条。

有些发条机械在上发条能力中列出了“待机”条目，它们可以通过一个[AAA]动作进入待机模式。在待机模式下，它的活动时间不会减少，但它可以感知周围环境（察觉检定有-2减值）。它无法行动，只有一个例外：当它感知到一个生物时，能以一个反应动作[R]退出待机模式（并且如果状况合适，则进行先攻检定）。

一个生物可以尝试对上了发条的发条机械进行@Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{解除装置 Disable Device}，解除DC在上发条能力中列出。每次成功的尝试都能减少发条机械1小时活动时间。这对于处于待机模式中的发条机械也能正常生效。

UK9gsjbHYgmKZze9.name: 自毁 Self-Destruct
UK9gsjbHYgmKZze9.description:
除非发条密探身处某些创造者编程时特别禁止的地点，否则发条密探一定会使用该反应动作

触发 发条密探的生命值减少至0

效果 发条密探带着一声细小的尖叫猛扑过来，然后发出倒计时的滴答声。在使用此反应动作后，当它的下一回合开始时，发条密探会自爆，对@Template[type:emanation|distance:5]{5尺半径}范围内造成[[/r {1d10}[piercing]]]{1d10穿刺伤害}（@Check[type:reflex|dc:16|basic:true]豁免）。它的宝石连同里面的所有信息都会被摧毁。

一个相邻的生物可以尝试通过@Check[type:thievery|dc:16|traits:action:disable-device]检定来@Compendium[pf2e.actionspf2e.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{解除装置 Disable a Device}，取消自毁程序。

Abandoned Zealot.name: 被弃狂徒 Abandoned Zealot
Abandoned Zealot.publicNotes:
当虔信者得知自身所信为假，曾被许诺的永恒本不存在，他们便化作被弃狂徒，从来世的门阶归返而来。它们因将自己的生命浪费于伪信仰与假信条上而厌恶自我，这份厌恶吞噬了这些迷失的灵魂，它们是可怕、无情——但终究是可悲的——敌人。它们破碎的面具下盘绕着一团不成形的烟雾和阴影。当被弃狂徒行动时，他们唾沫横飞，不断发出憎恶的咆哮、苦涩的叹息和悲哀的哭泣。

被弃狂徒通常与拉兹密尔（Razmir）教会联系在一起，该教会将一个凡人法师为奉神明——这是大多数崇拜者所不知道的事实。然而，如果他们对该宗教的教义或目标的理解被误导的话，被弃狂徒也可能来自一个真正的宗教。这种情况最有可能源于恶毒生物们残忍的计划与掠食，如（shrine skelms）和名为迪玛魔（deimavigga）的渎神魔鬼（blasphemous devils）。

Sense Apostate 500 feet.name: 感知叛党500尺
Sense Apostate 500 feet.description: 一个被弃狂徒可以在500尺内感知到伪牧师的存在和方向。铅或流水会阻隔这个感官。

Anathematic Aversion.name: 忿神怨己 Anathematic Aversion
Anathematic Aversion.description:
如果遇到与自己生前信仰相同的牧师，被弃狂徒必须进行意志豁免，DC等于这些牧师中最高的法术DC；如果他们都不会施法，DC则为牧师们最高的意志DC。被弃狂徒每分钟内只需进行一次豁免，即使之后有更多牧师到来。

大成功 被弃狂徒用一个反应动作向与它生前信仰相同的牧师行走。在1分钟内，被弃狂徒的绝望之手打击对这类牧师造成的伤害额外加一个伤害骰。

成功 被弃狂徒用一个反应动作向与它生前信仰相同的牧师行走。

失败 被弃狂徒获得@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{惊惧 Frightened 1}和@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.sDPxOjQ9kx2RZE8D]{逃跑 Fleeing}状态，直到下一回合结束。

大失败 如同失败，但是获得@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{惊惧 Frightened 2}。

Elegy of the Faithless.name: Elegy of the Faithless
Elegy of the Faithless.description:
Trigger A divine spell is cast within @Template[type:emanation|distance:30]{30 feet} of the abandoned zealot.

Effect The abandoned zealot howls an elegy of regret, forcing the spellcaster to attempt a @Check[type:will|dc:22] save, or a higher @Check[type:will|dc:24] if the caster is a member of the zealot's former faith. On a failure, the elegy disrupts the spell.

Rend Faith.name: Rend Faith
Rend Faith.description: When hit by an abandoned zealot's hand of despair, a creature capable of divine spellcasting or with divinely granted abilities must succeed at a @Check[type:will|dc:24] save or be unable to use those spells or abilities until the end of its next turn.

Abrikandilu.name: Abrikandilu
Abrikandilu.publicNotes:
Wrecker demons, also known as abrikandilus, despise beautiful things and do everything in their power to destroy both people and objects regarded as such. An abrikandilu forms from the souls mortals who were vandals, misanthropes, or defacers of artwork, particularly if their destructive actions stemmed from feelings of powerful envy.

An abrikandilu loathes only one thing more than beauty: their own visage. The mere sight of their face-reflected in a mirror, a shield, or even a pool of water- can send a wrecker demon into a rage. Many demon slayers leverage tactic to their advantage, venturing into battle with polished steel shields and cold iron blades at the ready.

Mortal souls that have been twisted and corrupted by sin sometimes arise in the afterlife as demons. These powerful and destructive fiends seek to spread their particular sin to warp more souls, thereby bolstering their numbers and continuing the cycle.

Hatred of Mirrors.name: Hatred of Mirrors
Hatred of Mirrors.description:
An abrikandilu loathes the sight of their reflection. When a creature Interacts with a mirror within sight of the wrecker demon, the demon takes a -2 penalty to Will saves against Intimidation checks.

An abrikandilu that ends their turn adjacent to a mirror or that's attacked by a creature holding a mirror takes [[/r {1d6}[mental]]]{1d6 mental damage} (this usually leads abrikandilus to focus their efforts on destroying nearby mirrors using Wreck).

Mutilating Bite.name: Mutilating Bite
Mutilating Bite.description:
When the abrikandilu hits a creature with a jaws Strike, the creature must succeed at a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:21] save or become physically mutilated.

The creature then takes a -1 status penalty to Charisma-based checks. This penalty is cumulative up to -3 and remains even if the wounds are healed.

The penalty is reduced by 1 every 24 hours until it reaches 0.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.LgZx5xotO08JzhVc]{Effect: Mutilating Bite}

Wreck.name: Wreck
Wreck.description:
The abrikandilu makes two claw Strikes against an unattended object or held mirror. Held mirrors use the holding character's AC.

If both Strikes hit, combine their damage for the purpose of overcoming any Hardness or resistance.

These Strikes don't count toward the abrikandilu's multiple attack penalty, nor does that penalty apply to these Strikes.

Adachros.name: Adachros
Adachros.publicNotes:
When a nascent demiplane fails to coalesce, its quintessence sometimes collapses into an adachros, a dangerous entity that combines overwhelming mental potential with no exposure to alternate viewpoints. Some of these megalomaniacal beings are tyrants, creating illusory kingdoms populated by abducted creatures forced to validate the creator's views. A more altruistic adachros might seek out pupils to reeducate and advise-though often without their consent-while always pushing their students to accept whatever unique philosophy was involved in their creation. An adachros might abandon disciples who spurn them, but more often, they become a bitter enemy, intent on destroying the perceived heretics.

The Astral Plane is a planar nexus, connecting the planes of the Inner Sphere to those of the Outer Sphere, a realm of timeless silver substance charged with mental essence drawn from throughout the Great Beyond. Most creatures on the Astral Plane are visitors-predators seeking to poach from the River of Souls, psychopomps guarding against such incursions, and aeons monitoring the flow of raw quintessence through the Antipode. Yet, this plane has spawned creatures native to its strange currents and eddies, foremost of which is the family of thought-spawned creatures known as ennosites.

An ennosite's form physically embodies of its thought and purpose. As some ideals and goals are shared, so are certain forms.

Self-Absorbed.description: The adachros denies any version of reality but their own. If they begin their turn under an enchantment or illusion effect, they immediately attempt to counteract one such effect with a counteract modifier of [[/r 1d20+23 #Counteract]]{+23}, even if the effect prevents the adachros from acting.

Splinter Sycophant.description:
Trigger The adachros takes 25 or more bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage

Effect The attack breaks off part of the adachros's body. This fragment reshapes and animates into an @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-bestiary-3.FXwgsLTRneGzclsw]{Ioton} with the minion trait under the adachros's control. The ioton sycophant can't move more than 120 feet from the adachros and crumbles after 1 minute.

If the adachros gives it no other commands, the ioton sycophant spends its turn praising the adachros and affirming the adachros's infallibility; this grants the adachros [[/r 4d6 #Temporary Hit Points]]{4d6 temporary Hit Points} that last for as long as the ioton sycophant exists, and a +1 status bonus to attack rolls, Perception checks, saving throws, and skill checks for 1 round.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.qddahkHks1iLZ4sM]{Effect: Praise Adachros}

Fatal Fantasia.description: An adachros's melee and ranged Strikes gain the fatal d12 trait against any creature affected by the adachros's enchantment or illusion spells, including creatures in the area of a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.HBJPsonQnWcC3qdX]{Hallucinatory Terrain} that haven't disbelieved the effect.

Adhukait.name: Adhukait
Adhukait.publicNotes:
Twice as disciplined as a monk and twice as deadly as a warrior, an adhukait is the ultimate perversion of duality, two spiked asura warriors impaled together to form one ferocious, incredibly efficient killing machine. An adhukait's two heads, two hearts, and two minds rarely work as one-except to maim or kill.

Even adhukaits' origin contains not one but two stories. Some believe they were created when two godlike brigands attempted to raid a celestial hall and had their bodies crushed together and thrown down from the heavens. Another legend states two asura twins once challenged a great warrior to duel them in turn. When they attacked him together, he was so enraged he slammed one into the other so hard that they were fused together from that day forth.

Adhukaits are among the most elite asura warriors, making up for what they lack in spellcraft with sheer viciousness and single-minded pursuit of inflicting pain.

Asuras are, above all, proof that the gods are not infallible. These fiends arose as physical manifestations of divine accidents, taking form when the gods themselves stumbled and blasphemed on a cosmic scale. As a result of their own divine genesis, an asura loves above all to undo the workings of the divine. They eagerly travel to the Material Plane, seeking out temples, congregations of faithful worshippers, and religious orders of all stripes to sow doubt and destroy what the gods seek to build.

Dual Mind.name: Dual Mind
Dual Mind.description:
Trigger The adhukait fails a saving throw against a mental effect

Effect The adhukait shunts the effect into one of their minds, rendering them temporarily insensible. They change their result to a success, but one of their bodies hangs limply until the end of their next turn.

During this time, the adhukait is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2}; takes a -10-foot circumstance penalty to their Speed; and can't use Dual Mind, Dual Opportunity, or Dance of Destruction.

Dual Opportunity.name: Dual Opportunity
Dual Opportunity.description: The adhukait gains a second reaction each round they can use only to make an Attack of Opportunity.

Dance of Destruction.name: Dance of Destruction
Dance of Destruction.description:
Requirements The adhukait's last action was a Strike that dealt damage.

Effect The adhukait Strides up to 10 feet and Strikes.

Adlet.name: Adlet
Adlet.publicNotes:
Adlets dwell in the farthest, harshest reaches of the Crown of the World. At first glance, these isolated people look much like their Erutaki human cousins; they typically have terra-cotta skin, straight black hair, and compact, powerful builds. However, adlets tend to be taller and more sinewy than their human kin. Up close, adlets' strangeness reveals itself-each sports a maw full of wolflike teeth. Their legs and tail resemble that of a dog.

Adlets' legends say that long ago, a mighty hunter lost his way far from home and came upon a house of whalebone and ice. A woman dressed in white fox furs greeted him, fed him, and tended to his frostbite. In time, they married and had 10 children, five of whom bore the legs and tails of foxes. These children stayed with their mother, while the other five-born with the legs and tails of wolves-traveled with their father back to the human lands and became the first adlets.

Adlets aren't inherently evil, but their culture is warlike, xenophobic, and noticeably lacking in humility. They see themselves as the natural rulers of the arctic wastes and view everyone else as squatters at best and invaders at worst. A typical adlet is stronger and faster than any mundane human, with the ability to walk naked in a blizzard and call up ice-cold mists. Given that, it's little wonder that adlets have developed something of a superiority complex. Still, while adlet raids are a common problem for travelers in the Crown of the World, a handful of wily and intrepid merchants have forged peaceful relations with certain adlet communities along more common routes.

Avenging Bite.name: Avenging Bite
Avenging Bite.description:
Trigger A creature within reach of an adlet's jaws Strike attacks one of the adlet's allies.

Effect The adlet makes a jaws Strike against the triggering creature.

Wolfstorm.name: Wolfstorm
Wolfstorm.description:
@Template[type:emanation|distance:60]{60 feet} @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.v61oEQaDdcRpaZ9X]{Aura}

A clammy, frigid mist billows forth ahead of the adlet. Creatures within the mist become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed}, and creatures outside the mist become concealed to creatures within it. An adlet can see through the aura without penalty.

Frozen Weapons.name: Frozen Weapons
Frozen Weapons.description: Weapons wielded by an adlet gain the effect of the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.M5M1WJ5KzbYfRGsY]{Frost} property rune.

Pack Attack.name: Pack Attack
Pack Attack.description: An adlet's Strikes deal an additional [[/r 2d6]] damage to creatures that are within the reach of at least two of the adlet's allies.

Wolfrime.name: Wolfrime
Wolfrime.description: An adlet's mist turns biting cold and coalesces into a thick rime of frost that deals [[/r {6d6}[cold]]]{6d6 cold damage} to creatures inside the adlet's wolfstorm aura (@Check[type:fortitude|dc:26|basic:true]), and the aura is deactivated until the start of the adlet's next turn.

Adult Forest Dragon.name: Adult Forest Dragon
Adult Forest Dragon.publicNotes:
Forest dragons oversee the endless growth of nature, protect it from plunder, and reclaim ruins for the wilderness. Some say these dragons jealously hoard nature's bounty for themselves while seeing everyone else who tries to benefit from nature as thieves and poachers. They loathe the progress of technology and civilization, preferring the company of monsters and animals.

Forest dragons are their forests in a literal sense. Over time, their hair becomes mossy, their hide toughens like bark, and small insects or animals live within them.

Imperial dragons, namesake of the Dragon Empires and guardians of Tian Xia before humanity arrived, embody five strengthening and counteracting forces. Unlike other true dragons, imperial dragons dive deep into human affairs. Some remain secretive, posing as reclusive hermits, while others keep a high profile, openly ruling factions. Tian cultures in turn venerate the dragons, depicting gods in the form of dragons or claiming ancestry from them. Not all are adored, for plenty of these creatures act wickedly.

Draconic Cycles

Five elements underpin the magical powers of imperial dragons, influencing their relationships to all things and, especially, to others of their kind. These elements interlink in two cycles. In the first cycle, each element feeds one other: wood feeds fire, fire feeds earth, earth feeds metal, metal feeds water, and water feeds wood. In the second cycle, each element counters another: wood counters earth, earth counters water, water counters fire, fire counters metal, and metal counters wood.

Each imperial dragon represents one element and has four abilities related to the cycle. For example, the forest dragon-linked to wood-feeds fire, is fed by water, counters earth, and is countered by metal.

Countered by Metal.name: Countered by Metal
Countered by Metal.description: If the forest dragon takes damage from a metal item, they lose woodland stride and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.zlnXpME1T2uvn8Lr]{Pass Without Trace} until the end of their next turn.

Fed by Water.name: Fed by Water
Fed by Water.description:
Frequency once per hour

Trigger The forest dragon is targeted with a water spell or effect

Effect The forest dragon gains [[/r 35 #Temporary Hit Points]]{35 temporary Hit Points}.

Frightful Presence.name: 气势凶猛 Frightful Presence
Frightful Presence.description:
@Template[type:emanation|distance:90]{90 feet} @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.v61oEQaDdcRpaZ9X]{Aura} @Check[type:will|dc:32]

Animals, fungi, and plants take a -2 circumstance penalty to the save.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.FrightfulPresence]

Breath Weapon.name: Breath Weapon
Breath Weapon.description:
The dragon unleashes a swarm of insects that deals [[/r {14d6}[piercing]]]{14d6 piercing damage} in a @Template[type:cone|distance:40] (@Check[type:reflex|dc:34|basic:true] save) before dispersing.

A creature that critically fails is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2} from the insects' venom; this is a poison effect.

The dragon can't use Breath Weapon again for [[/br 1d4 #Recharge Breath Weapon]]{1d4 rounds}.

Coiling Frenzy.name: Coiling Frenzy
Coiling Frenzy.description: The dragon makes one claw Strike and one tail Strike in either order, each against the same target. If either Strike hits, the dragon automatically @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabs} the target.

Draconic Momentum.name: Draconic Momentum
Draconic Momentum.description: The dragon recharges their Breath Weapon whenever they score a critical hit with a Strike.

Draining Blight.name: Draining Blight
Draining Blight.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The dragon draws moisture from the living creatures surrounding them, using the energy to heal their own wounds. Each living creature in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30] takes [[/r {7d10}[negative]]]{7d10 negative damage} (@Check[type:fortitude|dc:34|basic:true] save). Creatures made entirely of water and plant creatures use the outcome one degree of success worse than they rolled. The dragon regains Hit Points equal to half of the highest damage a single creature takes from this effect.

In addition, all non-creature plant life in the area withers and dies, eliminating non-magical undergrowth and any resulting difficult terrain, cover, and concealment. Water is also consumed in the same way, typically lowering any standing body of water fully within the area by 1 foot.

Forest Shape.name: Forest Shape
Forest Shape.description: When casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.dileJ0Yxqg76LMvu]{Tree Shape}, a forest dragon can become a tree of the same size and age as themself.

Woodland Stride.name: Woodland Stride
Woodland Stride.description: The forest dragon ignores difficult terrain and greater difficult terrain from non-magical foliage.

Adult Sea Dragon.name: Adult Sea Dragon
Adult Sea Dragon.publicNotes:
Sea dragons' affinity with water grants them mastery over rain, storms, and floods. Those whose livelihoods are at the mercy of the weather and waves frequently venerate these great aquatic creatures. Most sea dragons respond kindly to requests, but, like the sea, they can be unpredictable and fickle.

Sea dragons have disk-shaped scales like fish and webbed claws as well as large back and tail fins to aid in swimming. They appear in vivid and vibrant colors, like aquatic wildlife. Underwater flora and fauna grow and thrive upon older sea dragons, and ancient sea dragons often have a head of coral around their antlers, giving them the image of being crowned royalty.

Countered by Earth.name: Countered by Earth
Countered by Earth.description: If the sea dragon is targeted with an earth spell or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.znv4ECL7ZtuiagtA]{Flesh to Stone}, they lose Liquefy until the end of their next turn.

Fed by Metal.name: Fed by Metal
Fed by Metal.description:
When a sea dragon is struck by a weapon made primarily of metal or affected by a spell that uses metal, many of the dragon's scales transform to mimic the metal. This grants the dragon a +1 item bonus to AC until the start of their next turn.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.OMJnZspk5YHai8yn]{Effect: Fed by Metal}

Liquefy.name: Liquefy
Liquefy.description:
Trigger The dragon is targeted by a Strike or spell that could deal fire or physical damage to them

Effect The dragon liquefies, turning entirely to water while maintaining their shape, for a split second. Against the triggering effect, they gain resistance 20 to fire and to all physical damage.

Vortex.name: Vortex
Vortex.description:
@Template[type:emanation|distance:40]{40 feet} @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.v61oEQaDdcRpaZ9X]{Aura}

Water in the aura that's also in the same body of water as the dragon is difficult terrain for Swimming creatures which don't have the water trait.

Breath Weapon.name: Breath Weapon
Breath Weapon.description:
The dragon shoots a ball of water that deals [[/r {13d6}[bludgeoning]]]{13d6 bludgeoning damage} in a @Template[type:burst|distance:25] within 50 feet (@Check[type:reflex|dc:32|basic:true] save). All non-magical fire in the radius is extinguished.

The dragon can't use Breath Weapon again for [[/br 1d4 #Recharge Breath Weapon]]{1d4 rounds}.

Hyponatremia.name: Hyponatremia
Hyponatremia.description: A living creature that takes damage from the sea dragon's jaws Strike must succeed at a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:32] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} as a surge of excess water floods its body.

Adult Sky Dragon.name: Adult Sky Dragon
Adult Sky Dragon.publicNotes:
Sky dragons live above the clouds near the summits of mountains. They maintain a strong religious tradition, a unique practice among imperial dragons that sets them apart as much as their wings do. Desperate souls risk steep cliffs and loose snow to seek these dragons' counsel, and most sky dragons gladly help those who make the journey, but they expel any express hostilities or badger without hesitation.

The sky dragon's wings aren't true wings, but long fins fused to their forearms; their scales also form only very slowly. Young dragons coil tightly in their lairs as they absorb minerals that color and harden their scales. Even adults often wrap around pillars out of habit.

Adult Sky Dragon (Spellcaster).publicNotes:
Sky dragons live above the clouds near the summits of mountains. They maintain a strong religious tradition, a unique practice among imperial dragons that sets them apart as much as their wings do. Desperate souls risk steep cliffs and loose snow to seek these dragons' counsel, and most sky dragons gladly help those who make the journey, but they expel any express hostilities or badger without hesitation.

The sky dragon's wings aren't true wings, but long fins fused to their forearms; their scales also form only very slowly. Young dragons coil tightly in their lairs as they absorb minerals that color and harden their scales. Even adults often wrap around pillars out of habit.

Adult Sovereign Dragon.name: Adult Sovereign Dragon
Adult Sovereign Dragon.publicNotes:
The most well-known of imperial dragons due to their deep involvement with mortals, the sovereign dragons' name comes from their mandate of selecting rulers-but at some point, the dragons themselves joined the list of worthy candidates. Other imperial dragons suspect the sovereign dragons offered their connection to the elemental cycle to attain forbidden magic, evidenced by their lack of any vulnerability to wood or ability to feed on fire, despite being creatures of the earth.

Most hesitate to question the sovereigns' authority. While some appreciate their impartial nature, others fault this adherence to neutrality. Regardless, the sovereign dragons' charm and centuries of experience in subtle manipulation have made them exceptional negotiators.

Almost all sovereign dragons appear gold in color. Their hair ranges from common colors found among humans to bright reds, greens, or blues. They're the only dragons with five digits per claw, a mark of special importance. Other imperial dragons dismiss this claim to status and instead tease the sovereign dragons over their need to wear armor, even while in their draconic forms.

Adult Underworld Dragon.publicNotes:
Underworld dragons embody the pressure between tectonic plates, the heat behind geysers, and flash fires that ignite when the conditions are just right. Natural alchemists, they innately understand reagents and catalysts. While some research the effects of magic on material reactions, the majority of underworld dragons concentrate on building their hoards. Aghash.name: Aghash
Aghash.publicNotes:
Walking embodiments of curses, misfortune, and the evil eye, aghashes wander the deserts of the Material Plane, searching out the arrogant, charming, and persuasive to humiliate and undermine. Aghashes are often mistaken for some strange form of hag, and like those creatures, they're masters at curses.

Some fiends want to tear down the multiverse; others dedicate themselves to creating chaos and carnage, or to rule over realms with an iron fist. Divs strive toward a different, if equally reprehensible, goal-they seek to thwart and ruin the schemes and works of mortal beings.

Long ago, divs were once genies bound to serve ancient mortal empires lost to the passage of eons. In the beginning, these genies were masters of creation, working alongside gracious mortal partners to create works of subtle design and powerful magical potential. What started as a collaboration with mortals soon morphed into abuse, disrespect, and even slavery and bondage. Eventually, these genies rebelled, but in doing so, they came under the sway of a nihilistic demigod known as Ahriman. Their new master twisted their form and granted them the power to avenge themselves upon their mortal overlords, leading to the birth of the first divs.

Since that first wave of corruption, new divs arise from the spirits of the most wicked and hateful genies who die on the Material Plane, or those truly betrayed by mortals and overcome through their desire for vengeance. Upon such a death, instead of returning to the Elemental Planes, these genies' spirits are trapped in the dread orbit of Abaddon, where Ahriman reshapes them as divs and hoists them back to the world to wreak vengeance upon mortals.

Div Pact.name: Div Pact
Div Pact.description:
You call upon the powers of Abaddon to grant you the assistance of a div. You call upon a div whose level can be no more than double div pact's spell level, two divs whose levels are each at least 2 less than double the spell level, or three divs whose levels are each at least 3 less than double the spell level.

大成功 You conjure the div or divs, and they require nothing in return for their service.

成功 You conjure the div or divs. They are not eager to pursue the task, so they require a favor in return.

失败 you don't conjure any divs.

大失败 You don't conjure any divs, and they send a spiritual backlash that denies your use of any of your innate divine spells for 24 hours. If you are under the effect of any of your innate divine spells, the durations end.

Hatred of Beauty.name: Hatred of Beauty
Hatred of Beauty.description:
While aghashes hate all mortals, they particularly despise beautiful objects and beautiful or charismatic mortals. When not in physical peril, an aghash is compelled to destroy art and other works of beauty. An aghash can't enter an area of pristine beauty without first marring it in some way.

Given a choice, an aghash attacks a foe with the highest Charisma score first. If barred from doing so by force or some magical effect, they take [[/r {1d6}[mental]]]{1d6 mental damage} at the end of their turn.

Cursed Gaze.name: Cursed Gaze
Cursed Gaze.description:
The aghash fixes their gaze on one creature they can see within 20 feet. The creature must attempt a @Check[type:will|dc:21|traits:damaging-effect] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes [[/r {2d6}[mental]]]{2d6 mental damage} and becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1}.

Failure The creature takes [[/r {4d6}[mental]]]{4d6 mental damage} and becomes either @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1} (the aghash's choice).

Critical Failure The creature takes [[/r {8d6}[mental]]]{8d6 mental damage} and becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2}.

Sandstorm.name: Sandstorm
Sandstorm.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The aghash creates a temporary sandstorm in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30] that lasts for 1 minute.

Creatures within the emanation take a -4 circumstance penalty to Perception checks and must succeed at a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:18] save. On a failure, they're forced to hold their breath or else they start suffocating. A creature within the sandstorm at the end of its turn takes [[/r {1d6}[slashing]]]{1d6 slashing damage}.

Divs are immune to all effects of an aghash's sandstorm.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.f8rncEs06bqcn3LZ]{Effect: Sandstorm}

Air Wisp.name: Air Wisp
Air Wisp.publicNotes:
Air wisps are floating spheres of cloud and storm, perpetually humming a light, whispery tone. They're playful and capricious with great curiosity toward strangers.

Wisps are tiny elemental beings that emerged during the creation of the Elemental Planes. The first wisps roamed the Inner Sphere in shifting symphonies that traded members with their every meeting. These symphonies of free wisps created music out of their combined resonances, but when the evil Elemental Lords realized the value of the wisps' resonance, they captured whole symphonies for use as servants.

Wisps attune to each other and to those they surround themselves with. This attunement makes them naturally supportive allies. Free wisps still roam the Inner Sphere and the Material Plane, but they're usually shy and hide themselves from strangers. However, they happily offer their service to those who show them kindness. They especially find themselves drawn to spellcasters who practice elemental magic; these wisps usually watch from afar but sometimes approach those who seem safe to become familiars or comrades.

Free wisps who find one another become close almost immediately. They get especially excited when they find wisps of elements other than their own, showing none of the animosity some elementals exhibit toward other types. Instead, they join in an excited dance, emitting resonances that faintly echo the symphonies of ancient days.

Accord Essence.name: Accord Essence
Accord Essence.description:
Trigger An ally within 30 feet that benefited from the wisp's resonance in the last hour is targeted by an attack

Effect The wisp detonates itself in a small elemental explosion that gives temporary Hit Points equal to half the wisp's current Hit Points to allies within @Template[type:emanation|distance:30]{30 feet} that have benefited from the wisp's resonance in the last hour. These temporary Hit Points last 1 hour.

A wisp that uses this reaction is permanently destroyed, and it can be restored only by a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.6dDtGIUerazSHIOu]{Wish} spell or similarly powerful effect. If an ability would prevent the wisp's destruction (for instance, if the wisp is summoned and would merely be dismissed), Accord Essence has no effect.

Resonance.name: Resonance
Resonance.description:
@Template[type:emanation|distance:30]{30 feet} @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.v61oEQaDdcRpaZ9X]{Aura}

All wisps vibrate at a frequency attuned to their element, resonating with and empowering all creatures and effects sharing that trait.

A creature in the area gains a +1 status bonus to attack and damage rolls for effects with the air trait; a creature with the elemental and air traits gains this bonus to all attack and damage rolls.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.1dwMVgBHfT4qO4OS]{Effect: Resonance}

In Concert.name: In Concert
In Concert.description: When an air wisp rolls a critical failure on a check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW]{Aid}, they get a failure instead, and when they roll a success, they get a critical success instead.

Amalgamite.name: Amalgamite
Amalgamite.publicNotes:
Teleportation magic can prove a difficult undertaking, even for experienced spellcasters. It requires precise calculation and timing, knowledge of the intended destination, and meticulous control over surging conjuration magics. A mistake in even the most minute element of such a spell can lead to disastrous results for those involved. When a particularly powerful spellcaster makes an error of this kind, either through arrogance or simple misjudgment, they might transform into an amalgamite.

A mass of flesh and misaligned limbs, an amalgamite is the warped body of a former spellcaster, sometimes joined with another version of itself to incorporate additional limbs or other irregularities. They're still alive, but they have become aberrants mentally and physically, with only the vaguest memories of their previous existence, which makes them a dangerous and bewildering foe. Their weird, warped anatomy constantly shifts and regrows, allowing the creatures to shrug off physical blows save those that pierce through its flesh and into its core being.

The magical residue of an amalgamite's creation radiates from it, seeping into and destabilizing any living beings that get too close. Infected creatures then further spread the amalgamite's aura among larger groups of allies and foes alike. The amalgamite uses this power to manipulate and confuse their enemies, whom they can teleport into traps, force into confrontations with other enemies, or draw close into striking range with their own odd appendages.

Destabilizing Field.name: Destabilizing Field
Destabilizing Field.description:
@Template[type:emanation|distance:40]{40 feet} @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.v61oEQaDdcRpaZ9X]{Aura}

A creature that begins its turn within the area feels its body begin to stretch and must succeed at a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:33] save or become destabilized.

A destabilized creature emits a 10-foot destabilizing field aura and becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}. The destabilization ends when the creature is no longer sickened.

A creature that succeeds at its saving throw against the aura is temporarily immune to all destabilizing fields for 1 minute.

Displace.name: Displace
Displace.description:
Trigger The amalgamite is hit by a Strike.

Effect The amalgamite Repositions itself or Transposes itself with another creature. If the amalgamite successfully changes its location, it and any Transposed creature take half damage from the triggering Strike.

Reposition.name: Reposition
Reposition.description: The amalgamite teleports into an unoccupied space it can see within 50 feet.

Transpose.name: Transpose
Transpose.description:
The amalgamite chooses up to two destabilized creatures they can see within 50 feet and swaps their positions, or moves a single such creature to an unoccupied space they can see within range. If the amalgamite chooses two creatures, they can choose their self as one of these creatures, but both targets must be the same size.

An unwilling creature can attempt a @Check[type:will|dc:33] save. If either target succeeds at this saving throw, both are unaffected.

Amphisbaena.name: Amphisbaena
Amphisbaena.publicNotes:
An amphisbaena is an exceedingly aggressive, venomous viper of remarkable size that bears two heads-one on each end of its body. It moves in a manner similar to that of the more common sidewinder snake, throwing its body forward in a loop and anchoring itself by keeping one head or the other on the ground at all times.

Amphisbaenas' typical prey includes rabbits, foxes, various birds, small deer, and even humanoids if presented the opportunity. Fiercely territorial by nature, they attack just about anything that gets near their lairs, regardless of the intruder's size. Many a child has been warned about going too far into the woods alone, lest they wander too close to an amphisbaena den and become the creature's next meal.

The venom of an amphisbaena is incredibly potent, able to take down a stout dwarf within minutes if left untreated. However, it also has uses in a variety of healing remedies, which makes it a valuable commodity if collected. For example, a pregnant person might be advised to drink the venom in small, dilute doses to help safeguard the pregnancy. Mixing small amounts of the venom with various herbs and oil creates a poultice which dulls aches and pains. As a result, the image of an amphisbaena appears in many contexts associated with healing and alchemical subjects, such as labels for tinctures, annotations in herbalists' records, and illustrations in textbooks of medicine.

The first amphisbaena is said to have formed from the blood that fell as a medusa's head was severed. This story's origin most likely stems from the fact that amphisbaenas are oddly immune to petrification, which in turn leads to them sometimes being kept as pets by a medusa. A medusa who keeps an amphisbaena as a pet might regard the viper as their most treasured companion or perhaps even as their own child. Despite these fabled supernatural origins and the occasional special treatment they receive, however, amphisbaenas are entirely mundane animals with only rudimentary intelligence and no innate magical abilities whatsoever.

Amphisbaena Venom.name: Amphisbaena Venom
Amphisbaena Venom.description:
Saving Throw @Check[type:fortitude|dc:18]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 [[/r {1d6}[poison]]]{1d6 poison damage} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 [[/r {2d6}[poison]]]{2d6 poison damage} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} (1 round)

Stage 3 [[/r {3d6}[poison]]]{3d6 poison damage} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} (1 round)

Blinding Spittle.name: Blinding Spittle
Blinding Spittle.description: A creature critically hit by an amphisbaena's spit Strike is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round.

Twin Bites.name: Twin Bites
Twin Bites.description: An amphisbaena makes a fangs Strike with each of its heads, each against a different target. Both Strikes count toward its multiple attack penalty, but the penalty doesn't increase until after it has made both attacks.

Ancient Forest Dragon.name: Ancient Forest Dragon
Ancient Forest Dragon.publicNotes:
Forest dragons oversee the endless growth of nature, protect it from plunder, and reclaim ruins for the wilderness. Some say these dragons jealously hoard nature's bounty for themselves while seeing everyone else who tries to benefit from nature as thieves and poachers. They loathe the progress of technology and civilization, preferring the company of monsters and animals.

Forest dragons are their forests in a literal sense. Over time, their hair becomes mossy, their hide toughens like bark, and small insects or animals live within them.

Imperial dragons, namesake of the Dragon Empires and guardians of Tian Xia before humanity arrived, embody five strengthening and counteracting forces. Unlike other true dragons, imperial dragons dive deep into human affairs. Some remain secretive, posing as reclusive hermits, while others keep a high profile, openly ruling factions. Tian cultures in turn venerate the dragons, depicting gods in the form of dragons or claiming ancestry from them. Not all are adored, for plenty of these creatures act wickedly.

Draconic Cycles

Five elements underpin the magical powers of imperial dragons, influencing their relationships to all things and, especially, to others of their kind. These elements interlink in two cycles. In the first cycle, each element feeds one other: wood feeds fire, fire feeds earth, earth feeds metal, metal feeds water, and water feeds wood. In the second cycle, each element counters another: wood counters earth, earth counters water, water counters fire, fire counters metal, and metal counters wood.

Each imperial dragon represents one element and has four abilities related to the cycle. For example, the forest dragon-linked to wood-feeds fire, is fed by water, counters earth, and is countered by metal.

Countered by Metal.name: Countered by Metal
Countered by Metal.description: If the forest dragon takes damage from a metal item, they lose woodland stride and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.zlnXpME1T2uvn8Lr]{Pass Without Trace} until the end of their next turn.

Fed by Water.name: Fed by Water
Fed by Water.description:
Frequency once per hour

Trigger The forest dragon is targeted with a water spell or effect

Effect The forest dragon gains [[/r 40 #Temporary Hit Points]]{40 temporary Hit Points}.

Frightful Presence.name: 气势凶猛 Frightful Presence
Frightful Presence.description:
@Template[type:emanation|distance:90]{90 feet} @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.v61oEQaDdcRpaZ9X]{Aura} @Check[type:will|dc:39]

Animals, fungi, and plants take a -2 circumstance penalty to the save.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.FrightfulPresence]

Breath Weapon.name: Breath Weapon
Breath Weapon.description:
The dragon unleashes a swarm of insects that deals [[/r {20d6}[piercing]]]{20d6 piercing damage} in a @Template[type:cone|distance:60] (@Check[type:reflex|dc:41|basic:true] save) before dispersing.

A creature that critically fails is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2} from the insects' venom; this is a poison effect.

The dragon can't use Breath Weapon again for [[/br 1d4 #Recharge Breath Weapon]]{1d4 rounds}.

Coiling Frenzy.name: Coiling Frenzy
Coiling Frenzy.description: The dragon makes one claw Strike and one tail Strike in either order, each against the same target. If either Strike hits, the dragon automatically @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabs} the target.

Draconic Momentum.name: Draconic Momentum
Draconic Momentum.description: The dragon recharges their Breath Weapon whenever they score a critical hit with a Strike.

Draining Blight.name: Draining Blight
Draining Blight.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The dragon draws moisture from the living creatures surrounding them, using the energy to heal their own wounds. Each living creature in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30] takes [[/r {9d10}[negative]]]{9d10 negative damage} (@Check[type:fortitude|dc:41|basic:true] save). Creatures made entirely of water and plant creatures use the outcome one degree of success worse than they rolled. The dragon regains Hit Points equal to half of the highest damage a single creature takes from this effect.

In addition, all non-creature plant life in the area withers and dies, eliminating non-magical undergrowth and any resulting difficult terrain, cover, and concealment. Water is also consumed in the same way, typically lowering any standing body of water fully within the area by 1 foot.

Forest Shape.name: Forest Shape
Forest Shape.description: When casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.dileJ0Yxqg76LMvu]{Tree Shape}, a forest dragon can become a tree of the same size and age as themself.

Lignifying Bite.name: Lignifying Bite
Lignifying Bite.description:
When a creature made of flesh is reduced to 0 Hit Points by the dragon's jaws Strike, that creature must attempt a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:41] save. If it fails, it dies, and its flesh, made of earth in a metaphysical sense, turns to wood.

The wood is living and might grow into a tree over time, but it can't be used as a body or piece of a body for @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.IkGYwHRLhkuoGReG]{Raise Dead} or other magic that would return the creature to life.

Woodland Stride.name: Woodland Stride
Woodland Stride.description: The forest dragon ignores difficult terrain and greater difficult terrain from non-magical foliage.

Liquefy.description:
Trigger The dragon is targeted by a Strike or spell that could deal fire or physical damage to them

Vortex.description:
@Template[type:emanation|distance:60]{60 feet} @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.v61oEQaDdcRpaZ9X]{Aura}

Frequency once per 10 minutes

Requirements The dragon is in a body of water at least as large as they are

Failure The creature takes full damage, is pushed 120 feet from the dragon, and falls @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

Ancient Sovereign Dragon.name: Ancient Sovereign Dragon
Ancient Sovereign Dragon.publicNotes:
The most well-known of imperial dragons due to their deep involvement with mortals, the sovereign dragons' name comes from their mandate of selecting rulers-but at some point, the dragons themselves joined the list of worthy candidates. Other imperial dragons suspect the sovereign dragons offered their connection to the elemental cycle to attain forbidden magic, evidenced by their lack of any vulnerability to wood or ability to feed on fire, despite being creatures of the earth.

Most hesitate to question the sovereigns' authority. While some appreciate their impartial nature, others fault this adherence to neutrality. Regardless, the sovereign dragons' charm and centuries of experience in subtle manipulation have made them exceptional negotiators.

Almost all sovereign dragons appear gold in color. Their hair ranges from common colors found among humans to bright reds, greens, or blues. They're the only dragons with five digits per claw, a mark of special importance. Other imperial dragons dismiss this claim to status and instead tease the sovereign dragons over their need to wear armor, even while in their draconic forms.

Android Infiltrator.name: Android Infiltrator
Android Infiltrator.publicNotes:
Androids possess synthetic bodies inhabited by living souls. These technological organisms first came to Golarion from another world when their starship crashed, scattering wreckage all across Numeria in an event known as the Rain of Stars. Feared by local Kellids and enslaved by the Technic League, androids on Golarion have spent eons being hated and hunted. Many androids survive by adopting human customs and hiding in plain sight, while others become criminals, hermits, or nomads.

Designed to resemble humans, androids have several distinctive features. Their eyes have a metallic sheen, they rarely fall ill, and they have trouble displaying complex emotions. Circuit-like tattoos decorate their bodies and control internal nanites. When stimulated, these nanites kick their internal chemistry into overdrive, allowing them to function at peak performance that causes their circuitry to glow.

Androids are created in sophisticated machines called foundries. They emerge as mature adults with newborn souls and no knowledge of their purpose or the world around them. Android bodies don't deteriorate, though their souls age like any other mortal's. When an android feels they've lived a full life, they willingly release their soul to the afterlife, causing their body to shut down and reboot. Once this process, known as Renewal, completes, a new soul inhabits the body.

Foundry programming produces androids that mimic human anatomy. Numerous android models exist, each designed to excel at different tasks and purposes. Androids of all models display countless variations of coloration, body shapes, and gender identities. Theoretically, a foundry could be reprogrammed to create androids with new adaptations, colorations, and forms-perhaps even in the guise of other ancestries.

Emotionally Unaware.name: Emotionally Unaware
Emotionally Unaware.description: The android takes a -1 circumstance penalty to Diplomacy and Performance checks, and to Perception checks to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.1xRFPTFtWtGJ9ELw]{Sense Motive}.

Nanite Surge.description:
Trigger The android infiltrator attempts a skill check but hasn't rolled yet

Effect The android infiltrator stimulates their nanites, forcing their body to temporarily increase its efficiency. They gain a +2 status bonus to the triggering skill check. In addition, their circuitry glows, creating a 10-foot emanation with dim light for 1 round.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.rRgVlTHiNEJ86T7N]{Effect: Nanite Surge (Glow)}

Sneak Attack.name: 偷袭 Sneak Attack

The android infiltrator deals an additional 1d6 precision damage to flat-footed creatures.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.SneakAttack]

Angazhani.name: Angazhani
Angazhani.publicNotes: Angazhanis lurk in the depths of the world's jungles, where these sapient, four-armed apes prey on any creatures they deem lesser than themselves. They're purportedly the divine minions of Angazhan, demon lord of apes. While many angazhanis do worship this foul god, scarce evidence exists to support their claim to fiendish heritage. Jungle-dwelling people know well to steer clear of suspected angazhani territories; angazhanis of such areas don't slaughter outright, often capturing trespassers to serve as slaves or as living sacrifices in heinous rituals.

Defensive Disarm.name: Defensive Disarm
Defensive Disarm.description:
Trigger A creature makes a melee weapon Strike against the angazhani and misses

Requirements The angazhani is benefiting from their Defensive Slam

Effect The angazhani attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Dt6B1slsBy8ipJu9]{Disarm} the attacker of the triggering weapon.

Defensive Slam.name: Defensive Slam
Defensive Slam.description:
The angazhani uses their arms to defend themself while attacking. The angazhani Strikes once and gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC until the start of their next turn.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.BsuYuFxE20mnRxbs]{Effect: Defensive Slam}

Focused Slam.name: Focused Slam
Focused Slam.description:
The angazhani beats a single opponent with all four of their brawny arms, leaving their foe nowhere to dodge.

The angazhani makes a fist Strike. On a successful attack, they deal fist damage to the target plus an additional [[/r 3d8]] damage, and they meet the requirements to Rend the target this turn, even if they didn't hit on two consecutive Strikes. Even on a failed attack, the angazhani deals the damage from one fist Strike to the target, though they still miss completely on a critical failure.

This ability counts as four attacks toward an angazhani's multiple attack penalty. After using this ability, the angazhani is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Flat-Footed} until the beginning of their next turn.

Pummeling Charge.name: Pummeling Charge
Pummeling Charge.description: The angazhani rushes up to a foe at extreme speed and slams down with their fists. The angazhani Strides or Climbs up to three times, then makes two fist Strikes against one enemy within reach.

Angheuvore Flesh-Gnawer.name: Angheuvore Flesh-Gnawer
Angheuvore Flesh-Gnawer.publicNotes:
Angheuvores, or mortic elves, have an insatiable hunger for raw humanoid flesh-though they're reluctant to feed on other elves. Most stalk the streets of human nations, such as Druma, Razmiran, and the River Kingdoms. Impatient and impulsive, they're opportunistic hunters, preying on the wounded and isolated.

Mortics are humanoids overwhelmed by negative energy who still cling to life, surviving as twisted amalgams of living and undead. Though they feel unnatural cravings and resemble corpses, mortics live, breathe, eat, sleep, and procreate. However, a mortic can suspend their living functions simply by holding their breath, becoming more like a true undead.

Mortics are largely new to Golarion, with most created in droves when the Whispering Tyrant destroyed entire cities with his Radiant Fire, a magical explosion fueled by the collision of negative and positive energy. From among the corpses of these tragedies rose mortics, living survivors mistaken for corpses and left behind as a result. They found themselves in a twilight state-neither fully alive or undead. The necrotic pollutants of the Gravelands and the Isle of Terror continue to create mortics, seeping into neighboring lands through the air, earth, and water to infect the populace. Though most of the living in these lands fear becoming transformed, some believe becoming a mortic is their best chance of survival in the face of the encroaching hordes of the dead.

A mortic's powers differ by ancestry, though they do have a few commonalities. Reading or hearing scripture induces headaches, and they experience great discomfort when treading upon sacred ground. For those who were religious in life, these new changes can be devastating.

zXCRAQ4vboei7ilQ.name: 腐臭嗅觉 (模糊感官) 30 尺
zXCRAQ4vboei7ilQ.description: An angheuvore can smell creatures that have the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.yZRUzMqrMmfLu0V1]{Dying}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Yl48xTdMh3aeQYL2]{Wounded} condition as an imprecise sense.

Consecration Vulnerability.name: Consecration Vulnerability
Consecration Vulnerability.description: An angheuvore in a place of worship dedicated to a non-evil deity or on sacred ground, such as an area blessed by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.y3jlOfgsQH1JjkJE]{Sanctified Ground}, is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1}.

Death Gasp.name: Death Gasp
Death Gasp.description:
The angheuvore draws in a deep breath and holds it, temporarily suspending their biological processes and becoming undead.

The angheuvore gains the undead trait and becomes immune to bleed, death effects, disease, paralyzed, poison, and sleep. Any such effects the angheuvore is currently suffering from are suspended, but take effect again once they take a breath.

Death Gasp lasts as long as the angheuvore holds their breath (up to 8 rounds).

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.lyeRL7khixdlJsaf]{Effect: Death Gasp}

Invigorating Feast.name: Invigorating Feast
Invigorating Feast.description:
Requirements The angheuvore is adjacent to a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} creature, or a deceased creature that died in the last hour

Effect The angheuvore feasts upon the creature, dealing their jaws Strike damage (@Check[type:fortitude|dc:15|basic:true] save); a corpse automatically critically fails with no save. If the target takes damage, the angheuvore gains [[/r 5 #Temporary Hit Points]]{5 temporary Hit Points} and a +10-foot circumstance bonus to their Speeds for 1 minute.

Paralysis.name: Paralysis
Paralysis.description:
Any living creature hit by an angheuvore's jaws Strike must succeed at a @Check[type:fortitude|dc:15] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}.

It can attempt a new save to end the condition at the end of each of its turns, and the DC cumulatively decreases by 1 on each save.

Animated Colossus.name: Animated Colossus
Animated Colossus.publicNotes:
Animating a 100-foot-tall statue is worth the cost for spellcasters guarding immense dungeons.

Many animated objects have useful functions but become dangers when uncontrolled.

Construct Armor (Hardness 15).name: Construct Armor (Hardness 15)
Construct Armor (Hardness 15).description: Like normal objects, an animated colossus has Hardness. This Hardness reduces any damage the colossus takes by an amount equal to the Hardness. Once an animated colossus is reduced to fewer than half its Hit Points, or immediately upon being damaged by a critical hit, its construct armor breaks, removing the Hardness and reducing its Armor Class to 35.

Enormous.name: Enormous
Enormous.description: An animated colossus takes up a space of 6 squares by 6 squares (30 feet by 30 feet) and is 100 feet tall.

Colossus's Grasp.name: Colossus's Grasp
Colossus's Grasp.description:
The colossus can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Tkd8sH4pwFIPzqTr]{Grab} a creature using only one hand.

It can move normally with a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained} in its fist, carrying the creature along. If it has two creatures grabbed in this way, it can't use its fist Strike.

Animated Furnace.name: Animated Furnace
Animated Furnace.publicNotes:
This huge forge or oven is animated to protect a workspace or kitchen, travel alongside its owner, or both.

Many animated objects have useful functions but become dangers when uncontrolled.

Construct Armor (Hardness 10).name: Construct Armor (Hardness 10)
Construct Armor (Hardness 10).description: Like normal objects, an animated furnace has Hardness. This Hardness reduces any damage the furnace takes by an amount equal to the Hardness. Once an animated furnace is reduced to fewer than half its Hit Points, or immediately upon being damaged by a critical hit, its construct armor breaks, removing the Hardness and reducing its Armor Class to 26.

Fan the Flames.name: Fan the Flames
Fan the Flames.description: The animated furnace opens its door and fans its flames in a @Template[type:cone|distance:30] that deals [[/r {5d6}[fire]]]{5d6 fire damage} (@Check[type:reflex|dc:28|basic:true|traits:fire] save).

Animated Silverware Swarm.name: Animated Silverware Swarm
Animated Silverware Swarm.publicNotes:
Nobles are known to pay great amounts to animate their silverware, both for ease in cleaning and to serve as novelties during dinner parties.

Many animated objects have useful functions but become dangers when uncontrolled.

Construct Armor (Hardness 3).name: Construct Armor (Hardness 3)
Construct Armor (Hardness 3).description: Like normal objects, an animated silverware swarm has Hardness. This Hardness reduces any damage the swarm takes by an amount equal to the Hardness. Once an animated silverware swarm is reduced to fewer than half its Hit Points, or immediately upon being damaged by a critical hit, its construct armor breaks, removing the Hardness and reducing its Armor Class to 12.

Slice and Dice.name: Slice and Dice
Slice and Dice.description: Each enemy in the animated silverware swarm's space takes [[/r {1d6}[piercing]]]{1d6 piercing damage} or [[/r {1d6}[slashing]]]{1d6 slashing damage} (@Check[type:reflex|dc:17|basic:true] save)

Stick a Fork in It.name: Stick a Fork in It
Stick a Fork in It.description:
The animated silverware swarm attempts to pin a single creature.

The target must attempt a @Check[type:reflex|dc:17] save.

Critical Success The target is unaffected.

Success Silverware pins portions of the target's clothing and gear. The target takes a -10-foot circumstance penalty to its Speeds as long as it remains in the swarm's space.

Failure As success, and the target also can't Step until it leaves the swarm's space.

Critical Failure The target is thoroughly pinned by the silverware, becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} until it @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escapes} (DC 17) or uses 2 Interact actions to remove all of the silverware pinning them down.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.K3r1lfbtCTf3dFhV]{Effect: Stick a Fork in It}

Animated Trebuchet.name: Animated Trebuchet
Animated Trebuchet.publicNotes:
Large armies sometimes pay exorbitant fees to animate their siege weapons.

Many animated objects have useful functions but become dangers when uncontrolled.

Construct Armor (Hardness 14).name: Construct Armor (Hardness 14)
Construct Armor (Hardness 14).description: Like normal objects, an animated trebuchet has Hardness. This Hardness reduces any damage the trebuchet takes by an amount equal to the Hardness. Once an animated trebuchet is reduced to fewer than half its Hit Points, or immediately upon being damaged by a critical hit, its construct armor breaks, removing the Hardness and reducing its Armor Class to 32.

Launch.name: Launch
Launch.description:
Requirements The animated trebuchet has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} in its arm.

Effect The animated trebuchet attempts an Athletics check against the grabbed creature's Fortitude DC.

On a success, it fires the creature up to 40 feet in height and up to 120 feet away. The creature takes [[/r {4d12}[bludgeoning]]]{4d12 bludgeoning damage} plus the appropriate falling damage. If the flung creature lands on another creature, the creature it lands on takes the same amount of bludgeoning damage (@Check[type:reflex|dc:33|basic:true] save).

On a successful Launch, the animated trebuchet must Interact to reposition its arm into the proper position before it can Launch again.

Aphorite Sharpshooter.name: Aphorite Sharpshooter
Aphorite Sharpshooter.publicNotes:
The denizens of the Eternal City of Axis first forged aphorites to serve as emissaries, agents, and facilitators, with one foot in the sublime, perfect order of the Plane of Law, and one in the messy, murky, confusing muck of the Material Plane. In time, aphorites spread across the length and breadth of Golarion. Today they can be found in any corner of any land, and only a fraction still serve Axis directly.

Aphorites, like all planar scions, stand out quite vividly from their fellow mortals, sporting metallic skin, a faint coating of crystalline dust, a swirl of mathematical symbols, or perfectly symmetrical features. Many aphorites think logically and find satisfaction in careers dealing with numbers and information. Often, this leads them to become bookkeepers, clerks, or architects, but some become military engineers or sharpshooters. Others are drawn to the art of production, becoming blacksmiths, carpenters, engineers, architects, tailors, masons, or other such artisans. But no matter their careers, aphorites often feel the urge to tinker, and aphorite inventions draws both mockery and appreciation in equal measure.

Aphorites who work in less academic professions, such as mercenaries or laborers, sometimes hide their keen analytical intelligence beneath extravagant demeanors and flamboyant hats. Some craft even these disguises with the same depth and complexity they do others aspect of their lives, considering every theatrical mannerism carefully and planning out their every detail.

Planar scions are beings infused with the essences of other planes. While the examples presented here include humans with planar heritages, members of nearly any ancestry can be born with an influx of planar energies and become a planar scion.

Crystalline Dust.name: Crystalline Dust
Crystalline Dust.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The sharpshooter becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} for 4 rounds, though they can't use the concealment to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.XMcnh4cSI32tljXa]{Hide} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.VMozDqMMuK5kpoX4]{Sneak}, as normal for concealment where their position is obvious.

Calculated Reload.name: Calculated Reload
Calculated Reload.description: When the sharpshooter reloads their crossbow, they also calculate the best angle to their target, increasing the damage die from 1d8 to 1d10 and gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to their damage roll for their next crossbow Strike, as long as it occurs before the end of their next turn.

Hurtful Critique.name: Hurtful Critique
Hurtful Critique.description:
The sharpshooter makes witty, but disparaging comments about the fighting style of a target within 30 feet, expressing sympathy over every missed blow and providing sarcastic advice on how to improve.

The target must succeed at a @Check[type:will|dc:18] save or take a -1 circumstance penalty to attack rolls (-2 on a critical failure) for 1 minute or until it makes a successful Strike against the sharpshooter.

A creature who critically succeeds or who Strikes the sharpshooter after failing is immune to that sharpshooter's Hurtful Critique for 1 hour.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.HKyMZobjOsd6WFuo]{Effect: Hurtful Critique}

Arboreal Archive.name: Arboreal Archive
Arboreal Archive.publicNotes:
Arboreal archives are solitary beings typically found in the remote wilderness. These ancient monoliths hold the memories of their vast territories, keeping mental records of the passing seasons of the world around them. Their knowledge of humanoid affairs varies, as they find quickly shifting political situations difficult to comprehend, but through fungal networks, reports from arboreal wardens, and other woodland chatter, arboreal archives learn of each storm, drought, or logging threat encountered throughout their long years. They primarily observe and record rather than interfere, but they willingly offer wisdom to those who respectfully seek them out. Arboreal regents call upon archives for advice in times of strife, conferring on the best course of action to protect their realms.

It is rare for there to be more than one arboreal archive in a given region. When an archive senses they're nearing the end of their lengthy lifespan, a grove of regents gathers to nominate the wisest among them to become the next archive. After four seasons' deliberation, all arboreals in the area congregate to witness the succession ritual, during which the elder arboreal archive transfers their collected wisdom to the elected replacement before retiring.

Arboreals are tree-like ancient guardians of forests, nurturing new growth and maintaining a balanced ecosystem as if the vast wilderness were their garden. Arboreals are thoughtful and deliberate - until something threatens their realms and invites their wrath.

Abeyance Rift.name: Abeyance Rift
Abeyance Rift.description: If an arboreal archive dies unexpectedly before passing on their knowledge in a succession ritual, the amassed lore within their roots and boughs explodes out in a shock wave that deals [[/r {8d10}[mental]]]{8d10 mental damage} to creatures within @Template[type:emanation|distance:30]{30 feet} (@Check[type:will|dc:32|basic:true] save) before dissipating; those who fail also fall @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

Axe Vulnerability.name: Axe Vulnerability
Axe Vulnerability.description: An arboreal archive takes 10 additional damage from axes.

Memory Maelstrom.name: Memory Maelstrom
Memory Maelstrom.description:
The arboreal archive tries to overwhelm foes with a surge of information it has absorbed over its long life. This surge deals [[/r {5d6}[mental]]]{5d6 mental damage} to each enemy within @Template[type:emanation|distance:40]{40 feet}, who must attempt a @Check[type:will|dc:32|traits:damaging-effect] save.

Critical Success The creature maintains its composure, takes no damage, and is temporarily immune to Memory Maelstrom for 1 minute.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1} and takes half damage.

Failure The creature takes full damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 3}.

Critical Failure The creature takes double damage, is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for [[/br 2d4 #Duration Confusion]]{2d4 rounds}, and is stunned 3.

Arboreal Reaper.name: Arboreal Reaper
Arboreal Reaper.publicNotes:
While some forests have an idyllic, peaceful quality to them, others feel distinctly unfriendly or even sinister-these forests are the favored haunts of arboreal reapers. Sometimes these woodlands are sought out by secretive practitioners of malicious arts who claim the unsettling ambiance aids their abilities; arboreal reapers see no reason to interfere with such practices as long as the balance of their forests isn't harmed.

All arboreals vary in appearance based on their surroundings, but arboreal reapers always seem vaguely eerie, whether they watch over a grim weald or a tropical rain forest. Often slightly warped, twisted, and covered in spiky protrusions, arboreal reapers sometimes sprout around old ruins or other permanent structures, breaking down and incorporating the structures as they mature and become more mobile.

Arboreal reapers focus on the essential decaying phase of a forest's life cycle, becoming especially active in autumn and winter seasons. Their influence can often be seen in the explosion of mushrooms on a rotting log or the enticing fronds of a flourishing carnivorous plant. Like arboreal wardens, these woodland guardians are quicker to react to perceived threats than the more deliberate regents or retiring archives-at least by arboreal standards.

Arboreals are tree-like ancient guardians of forests, nurturing new growth and maintaining a balanced ecosystem as if the vast wilderness were their garden. Arboreals are thoughtful and deliberate - until something threatens their realms and invites their wrath.

Axe Vulnerability.name: Axe Vulnerability
Axe Vulnerability.description: An arboreal reaper takes 5 additional damage from axes.

Leech Moisture.name: Leech Moisture
Leech Moisture.description:
The arboreal reaper grows still and focuses intently on a single foe within 50 feet, draining moisture from the target's body. This deals [[/r {10d6}[negative]]]{10d6 negative damage} (@Check[type:fortitude|dc:25|basic:true] save).

The arboreal reaper can't Leech Moisture again for [[/br 1d4 #Recharge Leech Moisture]]{1d4 rounds}.

Azarketi Explorer.name: Azarketi Explorer
Azarketi Explorer.publicNotes:
